title: 105_hr2847
content: The Act is titled the "Higher Education Affordability and Availability Act" and references the Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997. It excludes education distributions from qualified tuition programs from gross income and covers private programs. The Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997, titled the "Higher Education Affordability and Availability Act," amends section 529(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code to exclude distributions for qualified higher education expenses from gross income. This provision allows for distributions that provide a benefit to the distributee, equivalent to payment of a qualified higher education expense, to not be included in gross income. The Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997 amends the Internal Revenue Code to exclude distributions for qualified higher education expenses from gross income. This provision ensures that distributions benefiting the distributee for educational expenses are not included in gross income. An additional tax is imposed on amounts not used for educational expenses from qualified tuition programs. The Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997 excludes distributions for qualified higher education expenses from gross income. An additional tax is imposed on amounts not used for educational expenses from qualified tuition programs. Amendments made by this act apply to distributions after December 31, 1997. The Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997 excludes distributions for education expenses from gross income, with amendments applying to distributions after December 31, 1997. Eligible educational institutions are permitted to maintain qualified tuition programs, with limitations on contributions to programs not maintained by a state. The Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997 allows for qualified tuition programs, with restrictions on contributions to programs not maintained by a state or agency. Contributions to such programs on behalf of a designated beneficiary are limited to $5,000 annually. The Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997 limits excess contributions to private education investment accounts to amounts exceeding $5,000 annually. Private education investment accounts include qualified tuition programs and education individual retirement accounts. The Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997 limits excess contributions to private education investment accounts to amounts exceeding $5,000 annually. Contributions distributed from education individual retirement accounts, contributions to qualified tuition programs, and rollover contributions are not taken into account for this limit. Amendments were made to section 26(b) of the Code to accommodate these rules. The Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997 limits excess contributions to private education investment accounts. Amendments were made to sections 529 and 530 of the Code to change references from "qualified State tuition program" to "qualified tuition program." Additionally, a new subparagraph (E) was added to section 529(f) regarding additional tax on certain distributions from qualified tuition programs. The Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997 made changes to sections 529 and 530 of the Code, including renaming "qualified State tuition program" to "qualified tuition program" and adding a new subparagraph (E) to section 529(f) regarding additional tax on certain distributions from qualified tuition programs. The Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997 amended section 529 of the Code by removing "State" from the table of sections and changing the effective date to January 1, 1998. It also allowed for the transfer of funds to another qualified tuition program for the designated beneficiary and included siblings as part of the family for the program. The Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997 amended section 529 of the Code to allow for the transfer of funds to another qualified tuition program for the designated beneficiary, including siblings as part of the family for the program. The amendments made by this subsection shall take effect on January 1, 1998.
